page.lettertext:
fol.312r
Belgia. 1590: No
v
:
Belgia 1590 3 Novem
b
To my L. Trea
s
May yt please yo
r
good L. notw
th
standing the ill successe
of
Co. Maurice
in his last attempt I adv
r
tised yo
r
L. the
28 of Oc
t
that I had resolved to go forward w
th
my practise
& to send some
son of purpose to view
e state of those
places, that I described unto yo
u
in my first information, hee
that is to bee employed shalbee gotten in
Zeeland
, and
one of
e
ties them selves by whom this matter was
disclosed unto mee, is already gon thether to make his choice
among his friend
. I cannot saie up
o
knowledge
t
e
Co. had any inkling, that her
Ma
ty
intended to und
r
take
t
enterprise, nor
t
hee thought to defeat yt by waie of p
r
vention
but his soddayn going thether before the weakenes of
e place
was thoroly discovered, & his concealing of his purpose
fr
o
e
Councell of state
w
th
oth
r
like conjectures might
minister some occasion to suspect his
ceeding. I writt
yo
r
L. in my last of
e grievous complaint
that are made
by this people, because theyr trafficq into
Spain
is empeached
by her Ma
ty
. The towne of
Middelboro
hath sent often
about yt to
e
generall states
, & there are at this p
nt
that
are newly come from thence c
r
tain clamorous m
r
chant
whose report
abroad are very rude & maligne. Being
spoken to by them to hold a good hand in theyr behalf, I
have told them of yt roundly, & have signified furder
that
e assembly heer of
e generall states is
e chiefest cause
of all this trouble to theyr countrey. For to the end there
might be some good order taken aswell for theyr traffique, as
for all oth
r
matters,
t
rest undecided between her Ma
ty
& these
Provinces, her Hig
nes
had bin pleased at
e instant sute of themselves
to send purposely hether & to propose c
r
tayne meanes for a
g
na
l redresse of all that eith
r
side complayned. Howbeyt not
onely
M
r
Wilk
whom her Ma
ty
sent to take theyr resolutions
was dismissed after 10 week
attendance, w
th
out any awnswer
to any thing proposed, but for the space of 10 weekes more w
ch
are
spent since hee de
ted, they nev
r
yet vouchsafed to send eyther
awnswer, or peece of any aunswere, or any kinde of letter
wherby her Ma
ty
might conjecture that they meant to give her
satisfaction. To reherse yt all
t
was in talke between us it
is but nedeles to yo
r
L. nevertheles becaus I sawe by theyr
awnswers, that they were very much choked w
th
e opposition, I
thought to mention yt unto yo
u
. They lett me furder und
r
stand
that
e states are bent out of hand to send a couple into
England
to make remonstrance to her Ma
ty
of all
e dommages don unto
them. Yt is thought
t
the
ties shalbe
Silla
pensioner
of
Amsterdam
fol.312v
Belgia: 1590: No
v
:
And
Vanderwerck
pensyonner of Middelburgh, two of those that
beare the greatest streake in
e meeting of
e states, & will
take any paines to crosse her Ma
tyes
ceeding
. As farr
as I can conceave this stopping of theyr traffqiue is a
very redy meane being followed effectually to force them
unto reason in all that is depending between her Ma
ty
& them
for yf they would bee revenged by seeking after
Fraunce
it is not now to be don, & to enter into treaty of accord
w
th
e ennemy, while her Ma
ty
is possessed & in good
assurance of her Cautionary Townes, yt is not thought they
will attempt, or can, if they would obtain a peace to theyr liking.
It is an opini
o
heer of many, and see s
o
tokens of likelihood
that they will frame some c
o
ference to o
r
last Propositi
o
s
and send it by the foresaid Deputies.
Having nothing els at
this p
nt
, to
i
t w
t
yo
r
L. I take my h
u
ble leave.
N
o
3. 1590.
